to get a statement writn into the report. - Paraguay would oppose
it. - He suggested that it might be well to raise the matter in the Con-
mission' and request that the ripporteur'' report be amended, then
debate could take place in the Commission with the vote there. MR.
Ur.TnNms agreed that it would be best to avoid discussion in the final
plenary session. MR. JOHNSON explained that he was not sure that an
amendment to the rapporteur's report would be 'accepted.- M.
BLoOM indicated that the report had not yet been approved as a whole.
MR. JOHNN agreed that there was still' 'Sme business for the Com-
mittee to do, and At least the point could be made in the record even
if it was not possible to havoe the amendment to the- report accepted
 BASSADO* tRoMYKO thought that- the proposal if mad by the
Five PoWers wbild be-ebpted by the danhmittee.
 AMIBASSADOR HALIFAX pointed out ithat even if it was not accepted
the statement, would be in the record, -supported by the Five Powers,
that the final power in the appointihent of -regional subcommittees
rests with the members of the Militaiy Staff Committee. AkMASSA-
DOR GRoxYIho asked why the Committee-would tot agree to the inter-
pretatido. If the opposition preferred uncertaih1Ay, it wioud seem to
him that they' perhaps thought that the regional agencies Haiu~t be in
agreement with the Military Staffs CoMnMittee before the regional sub-
committees could be appointed. Otherwise he wondered why the
interpretation would not be accepted.
 MR. St~rultus suggested that the matter should be left to the
Technical Committee. MR. JoHNsdit said he wold certainly do the
best he-cToifld to get the Committee vote approving they interpretatioih
to the rapporteur's report. AMBASSADOR HALIFAX said he would
1eave the matter with Mr. Johnson to find proper language."
 MR. S I NIUs asked whether there was any further business to
discuss.
 AMBASSADpOR GRoucho replied that'he had made his statement at the
Executive Committee and the Steering Committee to clarify his posi-
tion on the scope of the right of discussion in the Assembly.95 He
noted that the Executive Conumittee and the Steering Committee had
decided to appoint a subcosmmitt consisting of the Secretary, Mr.
Evatt, and himself. This Committee had met already, had talked
over the question, and there. had been no movement forward. The
Soviet Delegation believes that it would be best to stand on the Dum-
barton Oaks Proposals, but would have no objection to providing that
the General Assembly could discuss any matter within the-sphere of
international relations affecting the maintenance of international peace
